sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sara Dholakia)
articles.description: In this article, Sara Dholakia presents a guide on how to choose just the right type of data visualization, with guidelines and things to keep in mind.
articles.title: A Guide To Getting Data Visualization Right

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: That’s how people behave on the web in 2023. Some observations from real usability testing on what people do and what they don’t do on the web. From disabled copy-paste to magic link sign-in.
articles.title: The State Of Usability In 2023 🎊

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s start into the new year with a little inspiration boost: wallpapers created with love by the community for the community. Happy 2023!
articles.title: Opening The Doors To 2023 (January Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ruslan Yevych)
articles.description: In this article, Ruslan Yevych will show you an easy way how to predict the appearance of a problem known as WCAG Failure Under 1.4.4 Resize Text (AA) while zooming the page. You will have a clear understanding of the possible risks of using responsive typography at the stage of development.
articles.title: Fluid Typography: How To Predict A Problem With Your User’s Zoom-In

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Matvienko)
articles.description: Space is one of the core elements in design that is often overlooked. Proper spatial organization helps to achieve consistency between screens, pages, or even products. It also creates visual rhythm, limits decision-making, and helps to achieve better readability and scannability. In this guide, Paul Matvienko discusses the basics of defining a spatial system.
articles.title: An Ultimate Guide On Sizing, Spacing, Grids And Layout In Web And UI/UX Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alvin Bryan)
articles.description: No more random scripts in Python and JavaScript to transform CSV or JSON data. In this article, Alvin Bryan shows you how to use Miller, a small and powerful CLI tool, to do all your data processing.
articles.title: A Guide To Command-Line Data Manipulation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nicolas Hoffmann)
articles.description: You may have already heard of CSS logical properties or RTL adaptations but are still deciding whether to deploy them widely. To help raise your awareness of their possibilities, Nicolas Hoffmann shares his experience of how he and his team at Proton carried out a massive move from CSS logical props to production and how you can consider them from a different perspective in your very own projects.
articles.title: Deploying CSS Logical Properties On Web Apps

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Thomas Bohm)
articles.description: In this article, Thomas Bohm shares strategies and methods to tackle some common graphic communication problems and gives you insights into how to improve accessibility and usability and make your designs much better.
articles.title: Useful Accessibility And Usability Examples To Help Improve Your Designs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Masha Shaposhnikova)
articles.description: In this article, Masha goes over five tips that make it easier to manage a design system while increasing its effectiveness. This short guide is aimed at smaller teams.
articles.title: Taking The Stress Out Of Design System Management

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ashish Bogawat)
articles.description: In this article, Ashish Bogawat shares some of his favorite ways how to boost productivity and do things faster, better, and probably more fun by using efficient tools and workflows.
articles.title: Optimizing Your Design Workflow With Tools

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Suzanne Scacca)
articles.description: Concerns over online privacy and security are nothing new. In this article, Suzanne Scacca explores how the right CSV importer can help businesses better prioritize user security.
articles.title: How To Prioritize User Security When Collecting Offline Data

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Heather Burns)
articles.description: All of us want to create inclusive, safe, and privacy-aware digital experiences, but where to begin? Our brand new Smashing Book, “Understanding Privacy,” written by Heather Burns, can help you lay the ground for future developers, designers, and project managers to build a better web for tomorrow. [Jump to the details](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/12/understanding-privacy-new-smashing-book/#about-the-book) or [get the book right away](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/printed-books/understanding-privacy/).
articles.title: Understanding Privacy: Protect Your Users, Protect Yourself

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: There is no universal solution for making every kind of table responsive and usable on smaller screens, so we have to rely on various patterns, which Adrian explains in this two-part series.
articles.title: Accessible Front-End Patterns For Responsive Tables (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Keima Kai)
articles.description: In this article, Keima Kai provides a brief history of AI in web design, explores its current implications for creativity, and offers suggestions for how web designers can stay ahead of the curve.
articles.title: The Future Of Design: Human-Powered Or AI-Driven?

articles.title: Russian Turla Hackers Hijack Decade-Old Malware Infrastructure to Deploy New Backdoors

articles.description:
A South Africa-based threat actor known as Automated Libra has been observed employing CAPTCHA bypass techniques to create GitHub accounts in a programmatic fashion as part of a freejacking campaign dubbed PURPLEURCHIN.

articles.title: Hackers Using CAPTCHA Bypass Tactics in Freejacking Campaign on GitHub

articles.description:
Microsoft has shed light on four different ransomware families – KeRanger, FileCoder, MacRansom, and EvilQuest – that are known to impact Apple macOS systems.
"While these malware families are old, they exemplify the range of capabilities and malicious behavior possible on the platform," the tech giant's Security Threat Intelligence team said in a Thursday report.
The initial vector for these
articles.title: Microsoft Reveals Tactics Used by 4 Ransomware Families Targeting macOS

articles.description:
A variant of the infamous Dridex banking malware has set its sights on Apple's macOS operating system using a previously undocumented infection method, according to latest research.
It has "adopted a new technique to deliver documents embedded with malicious macros to users without having to pretend to be invoices or other business-related files," Trend Micro researcher Armando Nathaniel
articles.title: Dridex Malware Now Attacking macOS Systems with Novel Infection Method

articles.description:
Cloud services provider Rackspace on Thursday confirmed that the ransomware gang known as Play was responsible for last month's breach.
The security incident, which took place on December 2, 2022, leveraged a previously unknown security exploit to gain initial access to the Rackspace Hosted Exchange email environment.
"This zero-day exploit is associated with CVE-2022-41080," the Texas-based
articles.title: Rackspace Confirms Play Ransomware Gang Responsible for Recent Breach

Popular instant messaging service WhatsApp has launched support for proxy servers in the latest version of its Android and iOS apps, letting users circumvent government-imposed censorship and internet shutdowns.

articles.title: WhatsApp Introduces Proxy Support to Help Users Bypass Internet Censorship

articles.description:
A financially motivated threat actor tracked as Blind Eagle has resurfaced with a refined toolset and an elaborate infection chain as part of its attacks targeting organizations in Colombia and Ecuador.

articles.title: Blind Eagle Hackers Return with Refined Tools and Sophisticated Infection Chain

articles.title: Bluebottle Cybercrime Group Preys on Financial Sector in French-Speaking African Nations

articles.description:
Financial institutions are being targeted by a new version of Android malware called SpyNote at least since October 2022.

articles.title: SpyNote Strikes Again: Android Spyware Targeting Financial Institutions

articles.description: The latest breach announced by LastPass is a major cause for concern to security stakeholders. DevOps platform CircleCI on Wednesday urged its customers to rotate all their secrets following an unspecified security incident.

articles.title: CircleCI Urges Customers to Rotate Secrets Following Security Incident

articles.title: The Evolving Tactics of Vidar Stealer: From Phishing Emails to Social Media

articles.title: Irish Regulators Fine Facebook $414 Million for Forcing Users to Accept Targeted Ads

articles.description:
Qualcomm on Tuesday released patches to address multiple security flaws in its chipsets, some of which could be exploited to cause information disclosure and memory corruption.

articles.title: Qualcomm Chipsets and Lenovo BIOS Get Security Updates to Fix Multiple Flaws

articles.description:
Ransomware: contemporary threats, how to prevent them and how the FBI can help
In April 2021, Dutch supermarkets faced a food shortage. The cause wasn't a drought or a sudden surge in the demand for avocados. Rather, the reason was a ransomware attack. Tracked as CVE-2022-43931, the vulnerability carries a maximum severity rating of 10 on the CVSS scale and has been described as an out-of-bounds write bug in the remote desktop functionality in Synology VPN Plus Server.

articles.title: Synology Releases Patch for Critical RCE Vulnerability Affecting VPN Plus Servers

articles.description:
Challenges with an enforcement-based approach
An enforcement-based approach to security begins with a security policy backed by security controls, often heavy-handed and designed to prevent employees from engaging in risky behavior or inadvertently expanding the potential attack surface of an organization.

articles.title: Enforcement vs. Enrollment-based Security: How to Balance Security and Employee Trust

articles.title: Hackers Using Stolen Bank Information to Trick Victims into Downloading BitRAT Malware

articles.title: Raspberry Robin Worm Evolves to Attack Financial and Insurance Sectors in Europe

Chinese international students in the U.K. have been targeted by persistent Chinese-speaking scammers for over a year as part of an activity dubbed RedZei (aka RedThief).

articles.title: RedZei Chinese Scammers Targeting Chinese Students in the U.K.

articles.title: PyTorch Machine Learning Framework Compromised with Malicious Dependency

articles.title: WordPress Security Alert: New Linux Malware Exploiting Over Two Dozen CMS Flaws

articles.description:
Google has agreed to pay a total of $29.5 million to settle two different lawsuits brought by Indiana and Washington, D.C., over its "deceptive" location tracking practices.
The search and advertising giant is required to pay $9.5 million to D.C. and $20 million to Indiana after the states sued the company for charges that the company tracked users' locations without their express consent.

articles.title: BitKeep Confirms Cyber Attack, Loses Over $9 Million in Digital Currencies

articles.description:
Microsoft's decision to block Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros by default for Office files downloaded from the internet has led many threat actors to improvise their attack chains in recent months.

articles.title: APT Hackers Turn to Malicious Excel Add-ins as Initial Intrusion Vector

articles.title: BlueNoroff APT Hackers Using New Ways to Bypass Windows MotW Protection

articles.description:
Meta Platforms, the parent company of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp, has agreed to pay $725 million to settle a long-running class-action lawsuit filed in 2018.

articles.title: GuLoader Malware Utilizing New Techniques to Evade Security Software

The pay-per-install (PPI) malware downloader service known as PrivateLoader is being used to distribute a previously documented information-stealing malware dubbed RisePro.

articles.title: PrivateLoader PPI Service Found Distributing Info-Stealing RisePro Malware

articles.title: W4SP Stealer Discovered in Multiple PyPI Packages Under Various Names

The developers behind the Brave open-source web browser have revealed a new privacy-preserving data querying and retrieval system called FrodoPIR.
The idea, the company said, is to use the technology to build out a wide range of use cases such as safe browsing, checking passwords against breached databases, certificate revocation checks, and streaming, among others.

Tis the season for security and IT teams to send out that company-wide email: “No, our CEO does NOT want you to buy gift cards.”

articles.title: Vice Society Ransomware Attackers Adopt Robust Encryption Methods

The August 2022 security breach of LastPass may have been more severe than previously disclosed by the company.

articles.title: LastPass Admits to Severe Data Breach, Encrypted Password Vaults Stolen

articles.description:
An exhaustive analysis of FIN7 has unmasked the cybercrime syndicate's organizational hierarchy, alongside unraveling its role as an affiliate for mounting ransomware attacks.

articles.title: KmsdBot Botnet Suspected of Being Used as DDoS-for-Hire Service

articles.title: Researchers Discover Malicious PyPI Package Posing as SentinelOne SDK to Steal Data

The operators of the Glupteba botnet resurfaced in June 2022 as part of a renewed and "upscaled" campaign, months after Google disrupted the malicious activity.

articles.title: Glupteba Botnet Continues to Thrive Despite Google's Attempts to Disrupt It

articles.title: New Agenda Ransomware Variant, Written in Rust, Aiming at Critical Infrastructure

articles.title: Goodbye SHA-1: NIST Retires 27-Year-Old Widely Used Cryptographic Algorithm

articles.title: Android Malware Campaign Leverages Money-Lending Apps to Blackmail Victims
